questions.article:
The following text is from Mark Oshiro's 2018 novel Anger Is a Gift. In the novel, Moss and his friends are on a subway train in Northern California.

Lights from the outside world then filled the train car as it rose out of the ground and climbed the elevated track. As long as Moss had lived in West Oakland, he'd never tired of this specific view, so he pointed toward the windows. “Check it,” he said, and the Port of Oakland began to pass by them.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "specific" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Imaginary

options.name: B
options.content: Correct

options.name: C
options.content: Energetic

options.name: D
options.content: Particular

questions.correct: Particular

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from John Matheus's 1925 short story “Fog.”

The fog extended its tentacles over city and river, gradually obliterating traces of familiar landscapes. At five-thirty the old Panhandle bridge, supported by massive sandstone pillars, stalwart, as when erected fifty years before to serve a generation now passed behind the portals of life, had become a spectral outline against the sky.
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word "supported" most nearly mean?

options.name: A
options.content: Cherished

options.name: B
options.content: Defended

options.name: C
options.content: Held up

options.name: D
options.content: Improved on

questions.correct: Held up

questions.article: Although the government of the Soviet Union attempted to _____ Georgi Vladimov's novel Faithful Ruslan, copies of the book circulated in secret among readers in several parts of the country.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: replicate

options.name: B
options.content: import

options.name: C
options.content: suppress

options.name: D
options.content: critique

questions.correct: suppress

questions.article: Although the clustering of information technology firms in Northern California is often cited as typical of industrial agglomeration, Giulia Faggio et al. use UK data to show that the mix of factors driving the phenomenon is ___ across industries: while the potential for knowledge spillovers can prompt agglomeration, collocation among tube manufacturers occurs for different reasons.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: credible

options.name: B
options.content: heterogeneous

options.name: C
options.content: imperative

options.name: D
options.content: decisive

questions.correct: heterogeneous

questions.article:
The following text is from Anne Spencer's 1922 poem "Translation."

We trekked into a far country,
My friend and I.
Our deeper content was never spoken,
But each knew all the other said.
He told me how calm his soul was laid
By the lack of anvil and strife.
"The wooing kestrel," I said, "mutes his mating-note
To please the harmony of this sweet silence."
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the reference to the "wooing kestrel" (a type of bird) in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It emphasizes the speaker's belief that her friend is not sharing his true feelings with her.

options.name: B
options.content: It suggests that nature has secrets that humans are fundamentally incapable of discovering.

options.name: C
options.content: It illustrates the assertion that peace is a subjective state rather than an objective one.

options.name: D
options.content: It presents the natural world as aligning with the experience of the speaker and her friend.

questions.correct: It presents the natural world as aligning with the experience of the speaker and her friend.

questions.article: The 2021 novel My Heart Is a Chainsaw confirmed that Stephen Graham Jones is one of the most talented writers of horror fiction today. By featuring main characters who are Blackfeet, like Jones himself, the novel also helped to ensure that Indigenous people have a place within the horror genre. But Jones is hardly the only Indigenous voice in horror: Lisa Fuller, a member of the Murri people of Australia, has also written in the genre. Her acclaimed 2019 young adult novel Ghost Bird is set in a Murri community in Queensland, Australia.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence?

options.name: A
options.content: It predicts that non-Indigenous authors will include more Indigenous characters in their work.

options.name: B
options.content: It challenges the widely held view that Stephen Graham Jones based My Heart Is a Chainsaw on events in his own life.

options.name: C
options.content: It highlights the significance of the portrayal of Indigenous people in My Heart Is a Chainsaw.

options.name: D
options.content: It asks why so many readers who don't enjoy the horror genre have purchased My Heart Is a Chainsaw.

questions.correct: It highlights the significance of the portrayal of Indigenous people in My Heart Is a Chainsaw.

questions.article: Horizontal gene transfer involves the exchange of genetic material between organisms not in a parent-offspring relationship. It is common among prokaryotes (single-celled organisms, such as the bacteria Enterococcus cecorum and Moraxella caviae). The process can have the effect of increasing bacterial resistance to antibiotics; as such, an understanding of how to prevent horizontal gene transfer might result in the mitigation of dangerous pathogens (organisms that cause disease).
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It suggests that a commonly held belief regarding an organism is mistaken.

options.name: B
options.content: It summarizes the history of research into a biological phenomenon.

options.name: C
options.content: It illustrates why one organism may pose more of a threat than another.

options.name: D
options.content: It explains a practical benefit of researching a particular biological process.

questions.correct: It explains a practical benefit of researching a particular biological process.

questions.article: In 2013 Oona M. Lönnstedt and colleagues published a study concluding that ocean acidification has a strong effect on the behavior of Pomacentrus amboinensis, a species of fish. However, Lönnstedt and colleagues' study relied on a mean sample size of only about 28 fish. In a 2022 review of various scientists' conclusions about the impacts of ocean acidification on fish behavior, Jeff C. Clements and colleagues caution that relying on such a relatively small sample size can increase the potential for biased analysis. Such analysis, in turn, can contribute to reports of exaggerated effects.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main topic of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: A possible shortcoming of a study involving Pomacentrus amboinensis

options.name: B
options.content: A discovery regarding the evolution of Pomacentrus amboinensis

options.name: C
options.content: A change in fish behavior first reported in 2022

options.name: D
options.content: A newly identified cause of ocean acidification

questions.correct: A possible shortcoming of a study involving Pomacentrus amboinensis

questions.article: Historians point to the rule of the Piast dynasty as crucial to the formation of the Polish state. However, some differentiate between members of the dynasty like Wladyslaw I Herman, who ruled as duke from 1079 to 1102 CE, and less well-documented figures like Lestek, who is said to have ruled in the 9th and 10th centuries but whose historical actuality is disputed. Lestek appears in the Gesta principum Polonorum, a chronicle of medieval Polish history written between 1112 and 1118. However, the chronicle's documentation of Lestek relies on oral tradition, unlike its records of later rulers.
questions.question: According to the text, what is a difference between how historians view Lestek and how they view Wladyslaw I Herman?

options.name: A
options.content: Historians believe that the Gesta principum Polonorum provides more evidence for Lestek's existence than it does for Wladyslaw I Herman's existence.

options.name: B
options.content: Historians agree that Wladyslaw I Herman existed, but disagree about whether Lestek existed.

options.name: C
options.content: Historians agree that Lestek ruled Poland much later than Wladyslaw I Herman.

options.name: D
options.content: Historians find the orally transmitted stories affirming the existence of Wladyslaw I Herman to be more convincing than similar stories about Lestek.

questions.correct: Historians agree that Wladyslaw I Herman existed, but disagree about whether Lestek existed.

questions.article: It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45° north of the equator, like Lake Stechlin in Germany, to accumulate surface ice in winter. The amount and duration of ice depends on many factors, including local weather conditions as well as the lake's depth, volume, and surface area, but a climate researcher claims that the higher a lake's latitude, the more days per winter it will typically have measurable amounts of surface ice.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data in the table that support the researcher's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Näckten is at a higher latitude than Lake Kegonsa and typically had fewer days of ice per winter than Lake Kegonsa did.

options.name: B
options.content: Spirit Lake had 102 days of ice in the winter of 1980-81 and 126 days of ice in the winter of 2005-06.

options.name: C
options.content: Näckten had 177 days of ice in the winter of 1980-81 and 134 days of ice in the winter of 2005-06.

options.name: D
options.content: Näckten is at a higher latitude than Lake Kegonsa and typically had more days of ice per winter than Lake Kegonsa did.

questions.correct: Näckten is at a higher latitude than Lake Kegonsa and typically had more days of ice per winter than Lake Kegonsa did.

questions.article: The Cherokee Nation, the Quapaw Tribe, and the more than thirty other tribes in Oklahoma operate numerous businesses and generate billions of dollars in revenue. An economics student is researching the tribes' collective activity as a single industry. The student wants to compare the average amount that industry contributed per employee to Oklahoma's economy with the average amount contributed per employee by three other industries. Looking at the table, the student finds that tribal economic activity contributed over $141,000 per employee, on average, ranking it ________
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the comparison?

options.name: A
options.content: above all three of the other industries listed in the table.

options.name: B
options.content: above either administration/waste or construction and nearly equal to transportation/warehousing.

options.name: C
options.content: below all three of the other industries listed in the table.

options.name: D
options.content: below transportation/warehousing but above both construction and administration/waste.

questions.correct: below transportation/warehousing but above both construction and administration/waste.

questions.article: Uncle Vanya: Scenes from Country Life in Four Acts is an 1898 play by Anton Chekhov, originally written in Russian. In the play, Professor Serebrakoff and his wife Helena have come to stay at their country estate, which Vanya manages with the help of Sonia, the professor's daughter from a previous marriage. Chekhov depicts Vanya's opinion of Professor Serebrakoff as having changed significantly, as is evident when___
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of Uncle Vanya most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Vanya says to Professor Serebrakoff, “For twenty-five years I have managed [the country estate], and have sent you the returns from it like the most honest of servants, and you have never given me one single word of thanks for my work, not one- neither in my youth nor now.”

options.name: B
options.content: Professor Serebrakoff says to Helena, “It is funny that everybody listens to [Vanya] and his old idiot of a mother, but the moment I open my lips you all begin to feel ill-treated.”

options.name: C
options.content: Vanya says to Professor Serebrakoff, "This place [the country estate] could never have been bought had I not renounced my inheritance in favor of my sister [the professor's late wife],whom I deeply loved-and what is more, I worked for ten years like an ox, and paid off the debt."

options.name: D
options.content: Vanya says to himself, “I was proud of [Professor Serebrakoff] and of his learning; I received all his words and writings as inspired and now? Now he has retired, and what is the total of his life? A blank! He is absolutely unknown, and his fame has burst like a soap-bubble. I have been deceived; I see that now, basely deceived."

questions.correct: Vanya says to himself, “I was proud of [Professor Serebrakoff] and of his learning; I received all his words and writings as inspired and now? Now he has retired, and what is the total of his life? A blank! He is absolutely unknown, and his fame has burst like a soap-bubble. I have been deceived; I see that now, basely deceived."

questions.article: Jia Hu and colleagues hypothesized that workplace leaders who reflect on lessons learned from past mistakes are likely to exhibit more humility than leaders who don't engage in such reflection. To test this, the team placed 301 managers in one of three groups. Participants in two experimental groups were asked to reflect on a mistake, one group focusing on a mistake that resulted in learning and the other group focusing on a mistake that didn't result in learning. Participants in a control group were asked to reflect on their daily routine. All the participants then described how they would respond to a workplace scenario. After evaluating the responses for evidence of humility, the researchers concluded that their hypothesis was correct.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data in the graph that support the researchers' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: The managers who reflected on a past mistake that resulted in learning exhibited more humility on average than the managers in the other two groups did.

options.name: B
options.content: None of the three groups' average humility scores exceeded 3.5.

options.name: C
options.content: The managers in the control group exhibited only slightly less humility on average than the managers in the two experimental groups did.

options.name: D
options.content: All three groups exhibited less humility on average than the researchers expected.

questions.correct: The managers who reflected on a past mistake that resulted in learning exhibited more humility on average than the managers in the other two groups did.

questions.article: Nora Ephron's 1983 novel Heartburn is regularly described as autobiographical. That characterization is apt—there are many parallels between the experiences of the novel's narrator, Rachel Samstat, and those of Ephron—but it should not be taken to mean that all the people and events depicted in Heartburn are based on actual people and events. The novel is largely pure invention, and readers who neglect this fact and instead try to identify more and more real-life analogues thus risk___
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: overemphasizing the extent to which Ephron took inspiration from earlier writers.

options.name: B
options.content: positing unsupportable connections between Heartburn and Ephron's life.

options.name: C
options.content: misrepresenting Heartburn as being more widely read than it actually is.

options.name: D
options.content: minimizing the fact that Ephron drew on real-world material when writing Heartburn.

questions.correct: positing unsupportable connections between Heartburn and Ephron's life.

questions.article: What is the correct pronunciation of Kiribati? In the Gilbertese language spoken by residents of the island nation, the letter combination -ti makes the -s sound; as a result, the country's name ___ pronounced 'Kiribas'.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: is

options.name: B
options.content: are being

options.name: C
options.content: have been

options.name: D
options.content: are

questions.correct: is

questions.article: A recipient of both the Wolf Prize in Chemistry and the Robert A. Welch Award, chemist Ahmed Zewail expanded the limits of measurability when he devised a novel technique in optical spectroscopy that allows researchers___chemical reactions occurring within molecules at a quadrillionth of a second, or one femtosecond.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: to study

options.name: B
options.content: will study

options.name: C
options.content: who study

options.name: D
options.content: studying

questions.correct: to study

questions.article: Both Arteaga, in the state of Coahuila, and Lagos de Moreno, in the state of Jalisco, have been designated by Mexico as pueblos mágicos (magical villages) to celebrate these _______ natural beauty and unique cultural traditions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: town

options.name: B
options.content: town's

options.name: C
options.content: towns

options.name: D
options.content: towns'

questions.correct: towns'

questions.article: The size of bird eggs varies widely across species, and the researchers,____computer imaging to compare the lengths of eggs from species like Chloroceryle americana and Francolinus coqui, aimed to shed light on the evolutionary basis for such variation.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: using

options.name: B
options.content: to use

options.name: C
options.content: use

options.name: D
options.content: used

questions.correct: using

questions.article: A lady-in-waiting's account of Japanese courtly life in the tenth century, Sei Shōnagon's Pillow Book is filled with daily observations and musings. Some of these appear as ___ “Things That Arouse a Fond Memory of the Past,” Shōnagon catalogs her appreciation for pressed silk, a moonlit night, and dried hollyhock.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: lists: in

options.name: B
options.content: lists in

options.name: C
options.content: lists in:

options.name: D
options.content: lists, in

questions.correct: lists: in

questions.article: In his work, acclaimed Cahuilla___Gerald Clarke uses basketry, acrylic paintings, and other mediums to explore Native perspectives on truth and beauty.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: artist, and 2007 Eiteljorg Fellowship recipient

options.name: B
options.content: artist and 2007 Eiteljorg Fellowship recipient

options.name: C
options.content: artist and 2007 Eiteljorg Fellowship recipient-

options.name: D
options.content: artist and 2007 Eiteljorg Fellowship recipient,

questions.correct: artist and 2007 Eiteljorg Fellowship recipient

questions.article: Scientists long debated the origins of chondrules, tiny glass beads that formed in meteors billions of years ago; for decades, different theories were proposed, from lightning strikes to powerful rock collisions, but none had sufficient evidentiary support. ___ scientists found strong evidence that chondrules were formed by shock waves in nearby nebulae.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: Finally,

options.name: C
options.content: Similarly,

options.name: D
options.content: Therefore,

questions.correct: Finally,

questions.article: Voting members of the 2006 Latin Grammys were impressed by Los Tigres del Norte's album Historias Que Contar and its contribution to the norteño genre, a form of regional Mexican music featuring accordion and bajo sexto guitar that first developed in northern Mexico in the late nineteenth century. ___ they awarded the group the Best Norteño Album award.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: In contrast,

options.name: B
options.content: Accordingly,

options.name: C
options.content: Meanwhile,

options.name: D
options.content: Nevertheless,

questions.correct: Accordingly,

questions.article: As anthropologist Cristina Grasseni explains, with the rise in demand for artisanal cheeses claiming to be typical of specific Italian regions, such as Pecorino Siciliano cheese from Sicily, came the need to guarantee the veracity of such claims to consumers. ___ the European Union established DOP status, a label certifying that the cheese was made according to the region's local traditions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Conversely,

options.name: B
options.content: Likewise,

options.name: C
options.content: Regardless,

options.name: D
options.content: Therefore,

questions.correct: Therefore,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Chromosomes are cellular structures that contain genes.
  • Genes carry critical instructions for determining an organism's physical traits.
  • The fennec fox and the red fox are both species of foxes.
  • As a species, the fennec fox has sixty-four chromosomes.
  • As a species, the red fox has thirty-four chromosomes.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the two species of foxes. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Genes, which are in fennec fox chromosomes, carry critical instructions for determining the fox's physical traits.

options.name: B
options.content: While both are species of foxes, the fennec fox and the red fox don't have the same number of chromosomes: fennec foxes have sixty-four, whereas red foxes have only thirty-four.

options.name: C
options.content: The fennec fox and the red fox both have chromosomes, which contain genes.

options.name: D
options.content: The red fox, a species of fox, has thirty-four cellular structures called chromosomes.

questions.correct: While both are species of foxes, the fennec fox and the red fox don't have the same number of chromosomes: fennec foxes have sixty-four, whereas red foxes have only thirty-four.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Crown shyness is a phenomenon in which the tops (crowns) of neighboring trees grow close together but don't overlap.
  • To explain how this happens, Australian forester M.R. Jacobs proposes the mutual abrasion theory.
  • According to Jacobs's theory, when trees brush against one another, branches break off.
  • Malaysian scholar Francis S.P. Ng posits the mutual shade avoidance theory.
  • According to Ng's theory, when tree branches detect shade from nearby trees' branches, they stop growing.
questions.question: The student wants to compare the causes of crown shyness proposed in the two theories. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Ng posits the mutual shade avoidance theory, whereas Jacobs proposes an alternative theory.

options.name: B
options.content: Both Jacobs and Ng have proposed theories to explain what causes crown shyness.

options.name: C
options.content: While Jacobs proposes that crown shyness is caused by neighboring tree branches brushing against one another, Ng posits that it occurs when branches detect shade from nearby trees' branches.

options.name: D
options.content: Jacobs's mutual abrasion theory proposes that when neighboring trees brush against one another, branches break off, resulting in a phenomenon in which the tops of trees grow close together but don't overlap.

questions.correct: While Jacobs proposes that crown shyness is caused by neighboring tree branches brushing against one another, Ng posits that it occurs when branches detect shade from nearby trees' branches.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • In 2017, a research team led by Mary Caswell Stoddard determined the average lengths of eggs produced by various bird species.
  • Acrocephalus scirpaceus is a species of bird in the order Passeriformes.
  • Acrocephalus scirpaceus eggs had an average length of 1.80 cm.
  • Alcedo atthis is a species of bird in the order Coraciiformes.
  • Alcedo atthis eggs had an average length of 2.19 cm.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize a difference between the eggs of the two species?

options.name: A
options.content: A 2017 study compared the lengths of eggs produced by an array of different bird species, such as Acrocephalus scirpaceus and Alcedo atthis.

options.name: B
options.content: The bird species Acrocephalus scirpaceus, which belongs to the order Passeriformes, and Alcedo atthis, of the order Coraciiformes, were included in a 2017 study that compared the average lengths of their eggs.

options.name: C
options.content: Mary Caswell Stoddard led a research study that determined the average lengths of eggs, including those of Acrocephalus scirpaceus birds (1.80 cm) and Alcedo atthis birds (2.19 cm).

options.name: D
options.content: A 2017 study found that Acrocephalus scirpaceus eggs had an average length of 1.80 cm, whereas Alcedo atthis eggs were longer, with an average length of 2.19 cm.

questions.correct: A 2017 study found that Acrocephalus scirpaceus eggs had an average length of 1.80 cm, whereas Alcedo atthis eggs were longer, with an average length of 2.19 cm.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Understanding the history of science is critical for understanding how knowledge evolves.
  • Anna Vickers was a French algologist born in 1852.
  • She is known for her research on algae in the Canary Islands.
  • Margaret Crosfield was a British geologist born in 1859.
  • She is known for her research on the hills of Northeast Wales.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize a difference between Vickers and Crosfield?

options.name: A
options.content: Though it was conducted long ago, the research performed by algologist Anna Vickers and geologist Margaret Crosfield can help us understand how scientific knowledge evolves.

options.name: B
options.content: Algology and geology are just two examples of the myriad fields in which scientists can specialize.

options.name: C
options.content: Anna Vickers studied algae in the Canary Islands; Margaret Crosfield, however, studied the hills of Northeast Wales.

options.name: D
options.content: Both Anna Vickers and Margaret Crosfield are known for their contributions to science.

questions.correct: Anna Vickers studied algae in the Canary Islands; Margaret Crosfield, however, studied the hills of Northeast Wales.
